instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPUâ€™s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b, no chime, no brain, no video
threads.message:
[FONT=arial]Hi,
This <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b board came in not booting with no video.
Green light on the charger but no fan spin.
The Board had no signs of liquid damage, was very clean, with no corrosion.
I found out that <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3HOT</SIGNAL> was shorted to ground by cpu vcore.
<TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR> was short, so I[SIZE=12px] replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> as recommended in one of Louis videos.[/SIZE]
A trace was burned between Pin 3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR> and Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7555</RESISTOR>, I fixed this with a jumper.
This restored CPU Vcore :-)[/FONT]
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL>  = 0,896 V
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> =[FONT=arial] 0,811 V
But I still have no chime and no video.
Fan is spinning now, it starts slow but gets faster and faster upto high speed.
I've replaced SMC and BIOS with same result
Board beeps with no RAM installed.
Tried known good RAM.
No light on USB Mouse.
I inspected the area of <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, measured every single resistor around <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, everything is fine.[/FONT]



Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b, no chime, no brain, no video
threads.message: CPU will probably be dead. RIP.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b, no chime, no brain, no video
threads.message: Could be a bad CPU, the question is how did the initial damage happen. I bet it was liquid or someone fucking with it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b, no chime, no brain, no video
threads.message: My first guess was a dead CPU too. But I can really say that there was no history of liquid damage or prior repair attempt. I think the CPU just died when <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR> went short.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b, no chime, no brain, no video
threads.message: Are there any signals that I can measure, which should be missing, to proof that the CPU is definitely dead?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b, no chime, no brain, no video
threads.message: Not much to test besides slapping a known good CPU on there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b, no chime, no brain, no video
threads.message: Ok , thank you very much duke. Mark this as closed or solved.
